docs.lead_paragraph: In the charcoal-gray, predawn mist along the waterfront, Demetrio Beltran can just make out the forms of 40, maybe 50 trucks, stretching out in a daunting line in front of his Freightliner. It will be one, two, maybe even three unpaid hours before he can pick up his first load, and the mammoth lines, he says, not only are a daily indignity but are sabotaging his livelihood -- he earned slightly more than $20,000 last year despite his many 60-hour weeks.

headline.main: On the California Waterfront, Mostly Tough Times for Port Truckers

docs.abstract: Nation's 40,000 independent port truckers join demonstrations and strikes at all major ports, fed up with high fuel prices and falling incomes; many have gone from being unionized drivers with impressive wages and benefits, to being nonunion employees with lower wages and benefits as deregulation in late 1970's opened door to new, nonunion competitors; Teamsters' union seeks to unionize port truckers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Albert Turner, a civil rights leader and adviser to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Thursday in Selma, Ala. He was 64. Mr. Turner's heart stopped while he was being prepared for an operation to stop abdominal bleeding, said his brother, Robert.

headline.main: Albert Turner Is Dead at 64; Strove for Civil Rights in South

docs.abstract: Albert Turner, civil rights leader and adviser to late Rev Dr Martin Luther King Jr, dies at age 64; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Albert Turner, a civil rights leader and adviser to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., died on Thursday in Selma, Ala. He was 64.    Mr. Turner's heart stopped while he was being prepared for an operation to stop abdominal bleeding, said his...

docs.lead_paragraph: The students with purple hair, the graying academics with Jerry Garcia beards and the union organizers with their anti-W.T.O. buttons had crowded into a college auditorium in Minneapolis to hear some red-meat -- make that green-vegetable -- radicalism. And Ralph Nader, America's foremost anti-corporate curmudgeon, did not disappoint: Global corporations are sucking the life out of small businesses and family farms. Pollution is poisoning our rivers and air. Inner-city schools and health clinics are crumbling. And while the nation corrodes, the rich are buying and selling politicians like baseball cards.

headline.main: Nader Runs Again, This Time With Feeling

docs.abstract: Focus on presidential campaign of Ralph Nader, nation's foremost anti-corporate crusader who is running again as third party candidate, but on Green Party line; he insists current drive is serious, compared with 1996, when he refused to raise money, spent less than $5,000 and attracted barely 1 percent of vote; goal of current campaign is not to win, but to get more than 5 percent of vote to qualify for millions in federal campaign matching funds he says he would use to build Green Party; photo (M)
